channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israeli Defense Minister Talks of War’s Next Phase as U.S. Urges Civilian Safety
item.description: As pressure grows on Israel to scale back the war in Gaza, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III met with Israeli officials in Tel Aviv to discuss how Israel’s campaign could shift after 10 weeks of fighting.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of Alon Shamriz, one of the hostages mistakenly killed by Israeli soldiers, at his funeral in Shefayim, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Irish Leader Condemns Fire at Hotel Preparing to Host Asylum Seekers
item.description: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said there was no justification for “violence, arson or vandalism.” The blaze came weeks after an anti-immigrant riot in Dublin.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar of Ireland speaking to the media on Friday as he arrived in Brussels for an E.U. summit.

item.title: Pope Francis Allows Priests to Bless Same-Sex Couples
item.description: A church official said the blessings amounted to “a real development” that nevertheless did not amend “the traditional doctrine of the church about marriage.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican last year. The decision to allow blessings was based on his “pastoral vision,” officials said.

item.title: BP Pauses Oil Shipments Through Red Sea Amid Fears of Attacks
item.description: Global energy prices jumped as tensions escalated around the vital shipping route, where drone and missile assaults have prompted some companies to halt sending cargos.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cargo ships waiting in the Red Sea near the opening of the Suez Canal, in 2021.

item.title: Hong Kong Democracy Figure Jimmy Lai Stands Trial After Long Delay
item.description: Jimmy Lai, who published an antigovernment newspaper, faces up to life in prison if convicted on national security charges that rights activists have called baseless.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Alexandra Stevenson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai at Stanley Prison in Hong Kong in July.

item.title: Fear and Suspicion Stalk Russian Speakers in Latvia
item.description: In response to the war in Ukraine, Latvia has targeted residents with Russian passports as part of efforts to combat Moscow’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Katrina Kepule for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daugavpils, Latvia. More than 80 percent of the population in the city speaks Russian and few share Latvia’s enthusiasm for helping Ukraine.

item.title: Police Investigate Graffiti Found on Seoul’s Main Palace
item.description: For two consecutive nights, the Gyeongbokgung palace was spray-painted, in a country where such brazen vandalism is rare.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: The Gyeongbokgung grounds in Seoul in October.

item.title: Shrugging Off Egypt’s Crises, El-Sisi Gets Set for 6 More Years
item.description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is beginning his third term as Egypt’s president, presenting himself as a beacon of stability in a tough neighborhood even as his country’s economy shakes.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has survived crises and bouts of international condemnation since taking power in Egypt a decade ago.

item.title: North Korea Missile Was an ICBM, South Says
item.description: South Korea’s military said the ICBM, launched from near Pyongyang, flew high into space before landing in waters between the Korean Peninsula and Japan.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Seoul on Monday, with footage from an earlier North Korean missile launch.

item.title: More Than 100 Members of This Gaza Clan Have Been Killed in War
item.description: Family trees have been dismembered, and whole branches obliterated, since the war between Israel and Hamas broke out on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Iyad Abuheweila
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who were wounded in a strike on an al-Astal family home being treated last month at Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

item.title: The Overlooked Crisis in Congo: ‘We Live in War’
item.description: Six million have died, and more than six million are displaced after decades of fighting and the ensuing humanitarian crisis in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo, drawing in neighbors, mercenaries and militias. An upcoming election is inflaming tempers.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Arlette Bashizi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times

item.title: In Rightward Shift, New Zealand Reconsiders Pro-Maori Policies
item.description: The nation has long been lauded for trying to do right by its Indigenous people, but a new government may force a reckoning of Māori affairs.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Māori Party organized protests across New Zealand, including in the capital, Wellington, early this month against proposals to roll back policies that benefit the country’s Indigenous people.

item.title: How U.S. Is Pressing Israel to Rein in Gaza Assault
item.description: American officials are quick to say that Israel is in the driver’s seat in the Gaza war, but it is increasingly urging a change in course.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Israel’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant, rear left, meeting with U.S. Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III in Tel Aviv, on Monday.

item.title: China Earthquake Kills More Than 100 in Gansu and Qinghai Provinces
item.description: The 5.9-magnitude quake, which injured hundreds, struck Gansu Province around midnight. Survivors huddled in the freezing cold, setting fires to keep warm.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Rescuers in Chenjia, a village in Gansu Province, in the aftermath of the earthquake early Tuesday.

item.title: Iceland Volcano Erupts Near Grindavik After Weeks of Earthquakes
item.description: While Monday’s eruption was not unexpected, it was larger than volcanologists had been predicting and took place not far from an evacuated town and a power plant.
item.dc:creator: Egill Bjarnason and Claire Moses

item.title: U.S. Urges Israel to Protect Gaza Civilians
item.description: The American defense secretary reiterated “unshakable” support for Israeli security, but said protecting Palestinians was a “moral duty and a strategic imperative.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Lloyd J. Austin III, the U.S. defense secretary, and his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, in Tel Aviv on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: BP Paused Red Sea Oil Shipments
item.description: Plus corporate succession in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cargo ships waiting in the Red Sea near the opening of the Suez Canal, in 2021.

item.title: Ukraine Aid Bill Delayed as Border Talks Drag On
item.description: After a weekend of bipartisan negotiations, lawmakers were still short of a compromise and Republicans said they were reluctant to strike any agreement before the new year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: Migrants at the southern border. Senate negotiators have not been able to compromise on immigration policy legislation.

item.title: CIA Director Discusses Resuming Hostage Swaps Between Israel and Hamas
item.description: William J. Burns was in Warsaw on Monday, where he met with the head of Mossad, Israel’s spy agency, and the prime minister of Qatar, which has helped broker talks with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, on Capitol Hill in Washington in September.

item.title: The E.U. Is Investigating Elon Musk’s Platform X
item.description: The inquiry is perhaps the most substantial regulatory move to date against X, which has seen a rise in incendiary content on the platform, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:description: The social media platform X has scaled back its content moderation policies since Elon Musk bought the service last year.

item.title: The U.S. defense secretary arrives in Israel with a tougher message.
item.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has stressed both the Biden administration’s support for Israel and concerns about the rising Palestinian death toll.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III is in Israel for his second visit to the region since Israel launched a war in Gaza in retaliation for the Hamas-led terrorist attack on Oct. 7.

item.title: Austin Returns to Israel With a Tougher Message and Lessons Learned
item.description: The U.S. defense secretary has stressed both the Biden administration’s support for Israel and concerns about the rising Palestinian death toll.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the Biden administration navigates a crisis in Gaza, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III is taking a prominent role and also revealing more of himself.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: A push by Israel’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III will be in Israel, Bahrain and Qatar this week.

item.title: Serbia’s Leader Tightens Grip on Power in General Election, Early Results Show
item.description: The opposition had hoped to ride a wave of public revulsion at back-to-back mass shootings, but it was unable to convert the energy of street protests into a successful election challenge.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia celebrating his re-election on Sunday.

item.title: Israel’s Allies Urge Restraint as Netanyahu Vows ‘Fight to the End’
item.description: The U.S. defense secretary was headed to the Middle East as two top European officials called for a scaled-back war against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams, Adam Sella and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Smoke rising over the Gaza Strip on Sunday following Israeli strikes.

item.title: In Gaza, Israelis Display Tunnel Wide Enough to Handle Cars
item.description: The Israeli military took reporters on a tour of what it says is the biggest Hamas tunnel it has found since invading the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Israeli military escorted international journalists on a tour of what it says is the largest Hamas tunnel it has discovered to date.

item.title: Chile Rejects Conservative Constitution
item.description: For the second time in less than two years, Chileans voted thumbs down on a new national charter, and few seem to have the energy to try again.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Cristobal Olivares for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Santiago, Chile last week against adopting a new constitution.

item.title: AfD’s Tim Lochner Is Elected City Mayor of Pirna in Germany
item.description: The vote in Pirna fits into the Alternative for Germany party’s strategy of “normalization.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Tim Lochner, center, an independent backed by the nationalist party Alternative for Germany, was elected mayor of Pirna, in Germany’s east, on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: U.S. to Push Israel to Scale Back
item.description: Plus a dance protest craze spreads in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Gaza Hostage Deaths Weaken Netanyahu’s Grip on Power
item.description: The killing of three hostages in Gaza by Israeli soldiers adds domestic pressure on Benjamin Netanyahu as he resists international calls for a cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arriving for a cabinet meeting in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Guy Stern, Who Fled Germany and Then Interrogated Nazis, Dies at 101
item.description: He escaped as a teenager and later became one of the Ritchie Boys, a secret Army program that recruited refugees to gather battlefield intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: How Hungary Undermined an E.U. Effort to Give More Aid to Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban used E.U. rules on unanimous decisions to sink a $52 billion package strongly backed by larger countries.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary has embraced the veto as a disruptive weapon to shape European policy.

item.title: Chile Votes on New Conservative Constitution in Referendum
item.description: Chileans vote on a new constitution on Sunday that would pull the South American nation to the right. The process began with protests from the left.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Cristobal Olivares for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rallying against the proposed new constitution this month in Santiago, Chile’s capital. The vote on Sunday is the culmination of a four-year undertaking.

item.title: Buenos Aires Drenched by Storm That Killed 13 in Bahía Blanca
item.description: There were reports of power outages and damage across Argentina’s capital as it was swept by the storm that earlier had a deadly impact on the port city of Bahía Blanca.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:description: A satellite image of the storm near Buenos Aires on Saturday night.

item.title: At Least 61 Migrants Drown Off Libya, I.O.M. Says
item.description: The vessel set off with 86 people on board, the International Organization for Migration in Libya said, and women and children were among those who died in the shipwreck.
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Shoes of migrants on the beach in Qasr Alkayar, Libya, after their boat capsized in February.

item.title: Three Israeli Hostages Killed in Error Had White Flag, Israel Says
item.description: The military said the mistaken killing of the three men, who had been shirtless, was a violation of its rules of engagement.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ben Hubbard and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Families and supporters of Israeli hostages held by Hamas attending a rally calling for their return in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Vatican Sentences Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu to Over 5 Years for Fraud
item.description: The case raised questions about financial mismanagement at the highest levels of the church, and about Pope Francis’ power.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Cardinal Giovanni Angelo Becciu in 2018. He was sentenced to serve 5 and a half years on various charges on Saturday.

item.title: Gaza communications have been nearly blacked out for two days.
item.description: It was the fifth such blackout of phone and internet service in the territory since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Men walk past the rubble of a destroyed building in Gaza, where the conflict with Israel has led to another communications blackout.

item.title: A Sudanese City Took in Many Fleeing War. Now, Fighting Has Spread There.
item.description: Clashes on the outskirts of Wad Madani threaten a city that is the center of aid operations and home to tens of thousands of people displaced in an eight-month war.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Riding atop a truck along a road in Wad Madani, Sudan, on Friday, when witnesses and aid workers said heavy gunfire could be heard in several parts of the city’s suburbs.

item.title: In Search of Vintage Christmas Window Displays
item.description: The mechanically powered holiday scenes that once filled department-store windows in Canada are still humming. Here’s where to find them.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Despite being over 70 years old, the display at McCord Stewart Museum remains in good condition.

item.title: Sheikh Nawaf, Emir of Kuwait, Dies at 86
item.description: He was defense minister when Iraq invaded his tiny but oil-rich country, and he became ruler in his 80s.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:description: Sheikh Nawaf al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah in 2006. “We offer our condolences to the Kuwaiti people, Islamic and Arab nations and the people of the world,” the Kuwaiti royal court said in a statement upon his death.

item.title: Tensions Spilling Over From Gaza Impact Shipping in the Red Sea
item.description: Britain said that one of its warships had shot down a suspected attack drone, and several shipping companies have temporarily stopped sending vessels through the Red Sea.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Mike Ives and Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A container port in Barcelona last year.

item.title: Ukrainian Marines on ‘Suicide Mission’ in Crossing the Dnipro River
item.description: Soldiers frustrated by positive reports from Ukrainian officials break their silence, describing the effort as brutalizing and, ultimately, futile.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko, Olha Konovalova and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: For two months, Ukraine’s Marine Corps has been spearheading an assault across the Dnipro River in the southern region of Kherson to recapture territory from Russian troops.

item.title: Miss Universe Is Latest Target of Nicaragua Government Crackdown
item.description: Sheynnis Palacios, the first Nicaraguan to win the pageant, became a symbol of resistance. The authoritarian leadership soon came after people close to the competition.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Sheynnis Palacios of Nicaragua won the Miss Universe pageant last month in El Salvador.

item.title: The Debt Problem Is Enormous. Experts Say the System for Fixing It Is Broken
item.description: Economists offer alternatives to financial safeguards created when the U.S. was the pre-eminent superpower and climate change wasn’t on the agenda.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Political posters in Argentina, speaking to voter worries about high inflation.

item.title: Blue Carbon Is One of Many Companies Inking Carbon Market Deals
item.description: An Emirati company wants to broker a nascent market in which nations trade emission reductions even before regulations are agreed upon.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni and Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: A forest conservation project in Zimbabwe.

item.title: China Braces for Cold Wave After Snow Causes Train Crash
item.description: President Xi Jinping urged “all-out efforts” to ensure safety amid wintry conditions after a subway crash left hundreds injured in the capital.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fu and John Yoon
item.media:description: A section of the Great Wall of China at Shuiguan, north of Beijing, was covered in snow on Friday.

item.title: Israel Knew Hamas’s Money Source Years Before Oct. 7 Attacks
item.description: Agents worried as millions poured in. Hamas bought weapons and plotted an attack. The authorities now say the money helped lay the groundwork for the Oct. 7 assault on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker and Justin Scheck
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Running to a reinforced concrete shelter in Ashkelon, Israel, moments after a rocket siren was sounded on Oct. 7.

item.title: Israel mourns as the accidental killings of hostages reverberate.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv on Friday night demanding the return of the remaining hostages.

item.title: In India, There’s an App for Everything. Even Dream Babies.
item.description: Startups big and small are adding a modern touch to the ancient practice of instilling Hindu values starting in the womb.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leena Chauhan, 38, doing a meditation exercise guided by a pregnancy app at her home in Ahmedabad, India.

item.title: A Viral Dance and ‘Happiness Campaign’ Frustrates Iran’s Clerics
item.description: It all started when a 70-year-old fish market stall owner nicknamed “Booghy” was grooving in public, in violation of Iranian law.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar

item.title: Merle Goldman, a Leading Expert on Communist China, Dies at 92
item.description: A lifelong academic, she stood apart in her ability to communicate her insights about the country to nonacademic readers.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: In Israel, Jake Sullivan Denies Talk of a Rift Over Gaza War
item.description: “We’re not here to tell anybody, ‘You must do X, you must do Y,’” the national security adviser said. His visit came as the Israeli military said it had accidentally killed three Israeli hostages.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the president’s national security adviser, speaking in Jerusalem on Friday. He was the latest emissary from the Biden administration to visit Israel to discuss the war.

item.title: Al Jazeera Cameraman Killed and Bureau Chief Injured in Gaza
item.description: The journalists were covering the aftermath of airstrikes at a U.N. school-turned-shelter in Khan Younis. The bureau chief’s wife, son, daughter and grandson had been killed in October.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta, Traci Carl and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Colleagues and relatives mourn a Al Jazeera cameraman, Samer Abu Daqqa, at his funeral on Saturday after he was killed during an Israeli airstrike in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Senators Hold Up 43 Biden Diplomatic Nominees as Crises Roil World
item.description: The State Department says the monthslong blockade has damaged U.S. national security. Several Republican senators have objected to advancing the slate of nominees.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Kurt M. Campbell, right, the nominee for the No. 2 position in the State Department, is among those awaiting confirmation.

item.title: Lead Levels in Children’s Applesauce May Be Traced to Cinnamon Additive
item.description: The F.D.A. is investigating the sources of cinnamon and other ingredients produced outside the U.S. as the possible cause of lead poisoning in dozens of children. Advocates are urging mandatory testing of lead in food.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Food and Drug Administration, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Three products, WanaBana apple-cinnamon fruit purée pouches, Schnucks- and Weis-brand cinnamon-flavored applesauce pouches, were manufactured in a plant in Ecuador.

item.title: The U.S. Wants Israel to Scale Back the Gaza War. What Leverage Does It Have?
item.description: There are ways to persuade Israel to shift its strategy in Gaza, but each option carries a political and diplomatic cost for President Biden.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank operates near the border with Gaza. Israel receives about $3.8 billion in security aid from the United States each year.
